H0.text: Vaginal secretions are released to lubricate the vagina to facilitate intercourse.

H1.text: Urine is released to lubricate the vagina to facilitate intercourse.

H2.text: Blood is released to lubricate the vagina to facilitate intercourse.

H3.text: Semen is released to lubricate the vagina to facilitate intercourse.

A4.text: During sexual arousal and sexual intercourse, the amount of fluid in the vagina increases due to engorgement of blood vessels surrounding the vagina.

A5.text: Vaginal discharge is a mixture of liquid, cells, and bacteria that lubricate and protect the vagina.

A6.text: Plasma from the vaginal walls due to vascular engorgement is considered to be the chief lubrication source.

A7.text: Bartholin's glands, located slightly below and to the left and right of the introitus (vaginal opening), also secrete mucus to augment vaginal wall secretions.

A8.text: Vaginal lubrication (wetness; though this can occur without arousal due to infection or cervical mucus production around ovulation)
